case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952, from the decision dated the 22nd December, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta in Appeals Nos. Cal. 366/51, Cal. 69/52 and Cal. 70/52, arising out of the award dated the 9th February, 1952, of the Chairman, Industrial Tribunal, Delhi.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal decision dated September 22, 1952, setting aside award dated February 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from a decision dated September 22, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta setting aside an award dated February 9, 1952, made by the Industrial Tribunal constituted to adjudicate on certain disputes between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union.

facts.text: Several disputes between the Bank and its workmen referred on February 21, 1950, to Industrial Tribunal presided by Sri K. S. Campbell-Puri.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to this appeal may be briefly stated. Several other disputes between the parties had already been referred on February 21, 1950, to another Industrial Tribunal presided over by Sri K. S. Campbell-Puri, and during the pendency of the proceedings before the said Tribunal, the Bank alleged that the respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand illegally commenced a general strike on April 18,1951, in connection with a fresh dispute.

facts.text: Bank alleged that respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand commenced a general strike on April 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and during the pendency of the proceedings before the said Tribunal, the Bank alleged that the respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand illegally commenced a general strike on April 18,1951, in connection with a fresh dispute. Thereupon, notice was issued to the strikers that unless they returned to work by April 24, 1951, they would be deemed to have left service of their own accord.

facts.text: Strike was during pendency of proceedings before Campbell-Puri Tribunal, making it illegal under section 23(b) of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: and during the pendency of the proceedings before the said Tribunal, the Bank alleged that the respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand illegally commenced a general strike on April 18,1951, in connection with a fresh dispute.

facts.text: Notice issued to strikers to return to work by April 24, 1951, or deemed to have left service.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, notice was issued to the strikers that unless they returned to work by April 24, 1951, they would be deemed to have left service of their own accord. That notice having been ignored by the strikers a second notice was issued to them on April 27, 1951, terminating their service.

facts.text: Strikers ignored first notice, second notice issued on April 27, 1951, terminating their service.

anchor.surface_text: That notice having been ignored by the strikers a second notice was issued to them on April 27, 1951, terminating their service. The Government of India thereupon intervened, and as a result of the discussions held between the Government officials and the Bank, the latter agreed to take back all the employees except 150 against whom the Bank had objections on account of their alleged subversive activities and other objectionable and unlawful conduct before and during the strike.

facts.text: Government of India intervened after terminations, Bank agreed to take back all employees except 150 due to alleged subversive activities and objectionable conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India thereupon intervened, and as a result of the discussions held between the Government officials and the Bank, the latter agreed to take back all the employees except 150 against whom the Bank had objections on account of their alleged subversive activities and other objectionable and unlawful conduct before and during the strike. On July 2, 1951, the Government of India constituted a Tribunal to decide the questions regarding the dismissals etc. of the aforesaid 150 employees, and that Tribunal, after calling for the statements of case on behalf of the parties and hearing them, made an award on February 9, 1951, refusing reinstatement on the sole ground that the respondents had gone on an illegal strike in contravention of section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, and that the Bank was entitled to dismiss them.

facts.text: Government of India constituted Tribunal on July 2, 1951, to decide on dismissals of 150 employees.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1951, the Government of India constituted a Tribunal to decide the questions regarding the dismissals etc. of the aforesaid 150 employees, and that Tribunal, after calling for the statements of case on behalf of the parties and hearing them, made an award on February 9, 1951, refusing reinstatement on the sole ground that the respondents had gone on an illegal strike in contravention of section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, and that the Bank was entitled to dismiss them.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award dated February 9, 1952, refused reinstatement due to illegal strike under section 23(b), Bank entitled to dismiss, but granted half salary compensation from dismissal to publication.

anchor.surface_text: and that Tribunal, after calling for the statements of case on behalf of the parties and hearing them, made an award on February 9, 1951, refusing reinstatement on the sole ground that the respondents had gone on an illegal strike in contravention of section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, and that the Bank was entitled to dismiss them. The Tribunal, however, granted to the respondents compensation byway of salary and allowances at half the rates from the date of dismissal to the date of the publication of the award.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed strike was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal at Calcutta which, while agreeing with the Industrial Tribunal that the strike was illegal, held that it was condoned by the Bank and it was, therefore, not open to it to justify the dismissal of the respondents on the ground that they had participated in the illegal strike.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held that Bank condoned the illegal strike.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal at Calcutta which, while agreeing with the Industrial Tribunal that the strike was illegal, held that it was condoned by the Bank and it was, therefore, not open to it to justify the dismissal of the respondents on the ground that they had participated in the illegal strike.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held dismissal wrongful because no charges framed against respondents for violence or subversive activities, no explanation called for.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal further held that the dismissal of the respondents was wrongful because no charges were framed against any of them in respect of their alleged acts of violence or subversive activities and their explanation was not called for. The Appellate Tribunal accordingly thought that further evidence was necessary on certain specific points mentioned in its, order and reserved its decision as to whether the respondents were entitled to reinstatement till after such evidence was taken.

facts.text: No permission obtained under section 33 of Industrial Disputes Act for dismissal during pendency of proceedings before Campbell-Puri Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, no such permission was obtained. If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act, the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard on April 10, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: S. B. Chari and Hardyal Hardy for the respondents. 1953. April 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by PATANJALI SASTRI C. J.-This is an appeal by special leave from a decision dated September 22, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta setting aside an award dated February 9, 1952, made by the Industrial Tribunal constituted to adjudicate on certain disputes between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union.

facts.text: Appellant is Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: made by the Industrial Tribunal constituted to adjudicate on certain disputes between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi  hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union.

facts.text: Respondents are workmen represented by their Union.

anchor.surface_text: between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi  hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union. The facts leading to this appeal may be briefly stated.

facts.text: Bank objected to 150 employees due to alleged subversive activities and unlawful conduct before and during strike.

anchor.surface_text: the latter agreed to take back all the employees except 150 against whom the Bank had objections on account of their alleged subversive activities and other objectionable and unlawful conduct before and during the strike. On July 2, 1951, the Government of India constituted a Tribunal to decide the questions regarding the dismissals etc. of the aforesaid 150 employees,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal called for statements of case and heard parties before award.

anchor.surface_text: and that Tribunal, after calling for the statements of case on behalf of the parties and hearing them, made an award on February 9, 1951, refusing reinstatement on the sole ground that the respondents had gone on an illegal strike in contravention of section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds dismissal illegal under section 33 due to no permission during pendency.

anchor.surface_text: If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act, the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal.

facts.text: LAT directed further evidence on specific points and reserved decision on reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal accordingly thought that further evidence was necessary on certain specific points mentioned in its, order and reserved its decision as to whether the respondents were entitled to reinstatement till after such evidence was taken. Learned counsel for the Bank advanced a two-fold contention in support of this appeal.

facts.text: Section 33 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 prohibits dismissal without permission during pendency of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: That section provides, inter alia, that no employer shall, during the pendency of any proceedings before a tribunal in respect of any industrial dispute, discharge by way of dismissal or otherwise, any workman concerned in the dispute save with the permission in writing of the said Tribunal.

facts.text: No charges were framed against respondents for alleged acts of violence or subversive activities.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal further held that the dismissal of the respondents was wrongful because no charges were framed against any of them in respect of their alleged acts of violence or subversive activities and their explanation was not called for.

facts.text: Award publication date used for compensation end.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, granted to the respondents compensation byway of salary and allowances at half the rates from the date of dismissal to the date of the publication of the award. The respondents appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal at Calcutta which, while agreeing with the Industrial Tribunal that the strike was illegal,

Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952, from the decision dated the 22nd December, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta in Appeals Nos. Cal. 366/51, Cal. 69/52 and Cal. 70/52, arising out of the award dated the 9th February, 1952, of the Chairman, Industrial Tribunal, Delhi.

This is an appeal by special leave from a decision dated September 22, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta setting aside an award dated February 9, 1952, made by the Industrial Tribunal constituted to adjudicate on certain disputes between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union.

and that Tribunal, after calling for the statements of case on behalf of the parties and hearing them, made an award on February 9, 1951, refusing reinstatement on the sole ground that the respondents had gone on an illegal strike in contravention of section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, and that the Bank was entitled to dismiss them. The Tribunal, however, granted to the respondents compensation byway of salary and allowances at half the rates from the date of dismissal to the date of the publication of the award.

issues.text: Whether the Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents.

issues.text: Whether the dismissal of the respondents without permission under section 33 was illegal during pendency of proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, no such permission was obtained. If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act, the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal.

issues.text: Whether section 33 has no application because strikes are dealt with in Chapter V and respondents not concerned in pending disputes

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in the argument of the AttorneyGeneral that the section has no application to the case as strikes and lock-outs are dealt with in a different chapter, Chapter V, and as the respondents were no concerned in the disputes pending adjudication before Sri Campbell-Puri.

issues.text: Whether section 33 in Chapter VII is inconsistent with general application to all discharges

anchor.surface_text: The terms of section 33 are wide enough to cover the present case, and the fact that it finds place in Chapter VII headed Miscellaneous is by no means inconsistent with its general application to all cases of discharge on whatever ground it may be based.

issues.text: Whether the amendment by Act XLVIII of 1950 confirms general application of section 33

anchor.surface_text: This is shown by the recent amendment of the section by Act XLVIII of 1950 which has omitted the words except for misconduct not connected with the dispute in the newly substituted section.

anchor.surface_text: We consider it unnecessary to express any opinion on the question of condonation or waiver of the illegal strike for, assuming that there was no such condonation or waiver and it was open to the Bank to rely upon the illegal strike as a valid ground for dismissing the respondents, we are of opinion that section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents.

outcome.relief_summary: Rejected appellant Bank's contention that Labour Appellate Tribunal lacked jurisdiction to order reinstatement; held dismissal illegal under section 33 of Industrial Disputes Act for want of permission during pendency of proceedings

We consider it unnecessary to express any opinion on the question of condonation or waiver of the illegal strike for, assuming that there was no such condonation or waiver and it was open to the Bank to rely upon the illegal strike as a valid ground for dismissing the respondents, we are of opinion that section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents.

edges.explanation: Identical spans; holding declares dismissal without s33 permission illegal, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, no such permission was obtained. If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act, the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal.

We consider it unnecessary to express any opinion on the question of condonation or waiver of the illegal strike for, assuming that there was no such condonation or waiver and it was open to the Bank to rely upon the illegal strike as a valid ground for dismissing the respondents, we are of opinion that section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents.
r shall, during the pendency of any proceedings before a tribunal in respect of any industrial dispute, discharge by way of dismissal or otherwise, an

edges.explanation: Holding directly rejects the specific argument framed as the issue.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in the argument of the AttorneyGeneral that the section has no application to the case as strikes and lock-outs are dealt with in a different chapter, Chapter V, and as the respondents were no concerned in the disputes pending adjudication before Sri Campbell-Puri.

We consider it unnecessary to express any opinion on the question of condonation or waiver of the illegal strike for, assuming that there was no such condonation or waiver and it was open to the Bank to rely upon the illegal strike as a valid ground for dismissing the respondents, we are of opinion that section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of section 33 are wide enough to cover the present case, and the fact that it finds place in Chapter VII headed Miscellaneous is by no means inconsistent with its general application to all cases of discharge on whatever ground it may be based.

We consider it unnecessary to express any opinion on the question of condonation or waiver of the illegal strike for, assuming that there was no such condonation or waiver and it was open to the Bank to rely upon the illegal strike as a valid ground for dismissing the respondents, we are of opinion that section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents.
